messageBody:
I have thousands of JUnit tests in my system. Which of the following
two approaches will lead to consumption of lesser memory (if any
difference exists) and Why?

1st approach:
public class MovieListWindowPresentorTest {
MovieListWindowPresentor m;
MovieList ml;
Movie m1, m2, m3;
@Before
public void setUp() throws Exception {
m1 = new Movie("m1");
m2 = new Movie("m2");
m3 = new Movie("m3");
ml = new MovieList();
ml.add(m1);
ml.add(m2);
ml.add(m3);
m = new MovieListWindowPresentor(ml);
}
@Test
public void testGetAllMovieNames() {
String[] names = new String[] { m1.getName(), m2.getName(),
m3.getName() };
assertArrayEquals(names, m.getAllMovieNames());
}
@After
public void teardown() {
m1 = m2 = m3 = null;
ml = null;
m = null;
}
}

2nd Approach:
public class MovieListWindowPresentorTest {
Movie m1= new Movie("m1"), m2= new Movie("m2"),
m3= new Movie("m3");
MovieList ml = new MovieList();
MovieListWindowPresentor m = new MovieListWindowPresentor(ml);
@Before public void setUp() throws Exception {
ml.add(m1);
ml.add(m2);
ml.add(m3);
}
@Test
public void testGetAllMovieNames() {
String[] names = new String[] { m1.getName(), m2.getName(),
m3.getName() };
assertArrayEquals(names, m.getAllMovieNames());
}
}
With earlier version of JUnit the first approach would take less
memory because earlier versions (I think) used to retain the object
till the entire suite is complete.
